001/*  Written in 2016 by David Blackman and Sebastiano Vigna (vigna@acm.org)
002
003To the extent possible under law, the author has dedicated all copyright
004and related and neighboring rights to this software to the public domain
005worldwide. This software is distributed without any warranty.
006
007See <http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/>. */
008package squidpony.squidmath;
009
010import squidpony.StringKit;
011
012import java.io.Serializable;
013
014/**
015 * A Linear Feedback Shift Register that may be used like a StatefulRandomness but is not truly random. This has a
016 * period of (2 to the 64) minus 1, and is based on Wikipedia's code for a Galois LFSR but uses data from
017 * http://web.archive.org/web/20161007061934/http://courses.cse.tamu.edu/csce680/walker/lfsr_table.pdf .
018 * It is important to note that an LFSR will produce each number from 1 until its maximum exactly once before repeating,
019 * so this may be useful as a way of generating test data in an unpredictable order.
020 * @author Tommy Ettinger
021 */
022public class LFSR implements StatefulRandomness, Serializable {
023
024        private static final long DOUBLE_MASK = (1L << 53) - 1;
025    private static final double NORM_53 = 1. / (1L << 53);
026    private static final long FLOAT_MASK = (1L << 24) - 1;
027    private static final double NORM_24 = 1. / (1L << 24);
028
029        private static final long serialVersionUID = -2373549048478690398L;
030
031    public long state;
032
033    /**
034     * Creates a new generator seeded using Math.random.
035     */
036    public LFSR() {
037        this((long) (Math.random() * Long.MAX_VALUE));
038    }
039
040    public LFSR(final long seed) {
041        setState(seed);
042    }
043
044    public LFSR(final CharSequence seed)
045    {
046        this(CrossHash.hash64(seed));
047    }
048
049
050    @Override
051    public final int next(int bits) {
052        return (int)nextLong() >>> (32 - bits);
053    }
054
055    @Override
056    public final long nextLong() {
057        return state = (state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1L) & 0xD800000000000000L));
058    }
059
060    /**
061     * Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the
062     * copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just needs to
063     * copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
064     *
065     * @return a copy of this RandomnessSource
066     */
067    @Override
068    public LFSR copy() {
069        return new LFSR(state);
070    }
071
072
073    /**
074     * Can return any int, positive or negative, of any size permissible in a 32-bit signed integer.
075     * @return any int, all 32 bits are random
076     */
077    public int nextInt() {
078        return (int)nextLong();
079    }
080
081    /**
082     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0.
083     * The bound should not be negative; use {@link IRNG#nextSignedInt(int)} if you need a negative outer bound.
084     * 
085     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; should be positive
086     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
087     */
088    public int nextInt( final int bound ) {
089        return (int)((bound * (nextLong() & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
090    }
091    /**
092     * Inclusive lower, exclusive upper.
093     * @param inner the inner bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
094     * @param outer the outer bound, exclusive, should be positive, should be greater than inner
095     * @return a random int that may be equal to inner and will otherwise be between inner and outer
096     */
097    public int nextInt(final int inner, final int outer) {
098        return inner + nextInt(outer - inner);
099    }
100
101    /**
102     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0. The bound may be negative, which will produce a non-positive
103     * result.
104     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be positive or negative
105     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
106     */
107    public long nextLong(long bound) {
108        long rand = nextLong();
109        final long randLow = rand & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
110        final long boundLow = bound & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
111        rand >>>= 32;
112        bound >>= 32;
113        final long t = rand * boundLow + (randLow * boundLow >>> 32);
114        return rand * bound + (t >> 32) + (randLow * bound + (t & 0xFFFFFFFFL) >> 32);
115    }
116
117    /**
118     * Inclusive inner, exclusive outer; both inner and outer can be positive or negative.
119     * @param inner the inner bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
120     * @param outer the outer bound, exclusive, can be positive or negative and may be greater than or less than inner
121     * @return a random long that may be equal to inner and will otherwise be between inner and outer
122     */
123    public long nextLong(final long inner, final long outer) {
124        return inner + nextLong(outer - inner);
125    }
126
127    public double nextDouble() {
128        return (nextLong() & DOUBLE_MASK) * NORM_53;
129    }
130
131    public float nextFloat() {
132        return (float) ((nextLong() & FLOAT_MASK) * NORM_24);
133    }
134
135    public boolean nextBoolean() {
136        return nextLong() < 0L;
137    }
138
139    public void nextBytes(final byte[] bytes) {
140        int i = bytes.length, n;
141        while (i != 0) {
142            n = Math.min(i, 8);
143            for (long bits = nextLong(); n-- != 0; bits >>>= 8) {
144                bytes[--i] = (byte) bits;
145            }
146        }
147    }
148
149    /**
150     * Get the current internal state of the StatefulRandomness as a long.
151     *
152     * @return the current internal state of this object.
153     */
154    @Override
155    public long getState() {
156        return state;
157    }
158
159    /**
160     * Sets the seed of this generator using one long, running that through LightRNG's algorithm twice to get the state.
161     * @param seed the number to use as the seed
162     */
163    public void setState(final long seed) {
164        if(seed == 0)
165            state = -1L;
166        else
167            state = seed;
168    }
169
170    @Override
171    public String toString() {
172        return "LFSR with state 0x" + StringKit.hex(state) + 'L';
173    }
174
175    @Override
176    public boolean equals(Object o) {
177        if (this == o) return true;
178        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
179
180        LFSR lfsr = (LFSR) o;
181
182        return (state == lfsr.state);
183    }
184
185    @Override
186    public int hashCode() {
187        return (int) (state ^ (state >>> 32));
188    }
189
190    /**
191     * Gets the next number that an LFSR would produce using {@link #nextLong()} if its state was {@code state}.
192     * Does not allow state to be 0. Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you expect
193     * to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determine(state))}, which will ensure the long-term
194     * properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 64) minus 1), or the guarantee that every
195     * number from 1 to ((2 to the 64) minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
196     * @param state any long other than 0
197     * @return the next long that a 64-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
198     */
199    public static long determine(final long state)
200    {
201        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1L) & 0xD800000000000000L);
202    }
203
204    /**
205     * Gets the next number from 1 to 255 that a different kind of LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
206     * Does not allow state to be 0. If given all byte values except 0 as arguments, will produce all ints 1-255.
207     * Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you expect to call this again, such as
208     * with {@code (state = LFSR.determineByte(state))}, which will ensure the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up
209     * (such as having a period of 255, or the guarantee that every number from 1 to 255, inclusive on both, will be
210     * generated once per period).
211     * @param state any byte other than 0
212     * @return the next int between 1 and 255 that an 8-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
213     */
214    public static int determineByte(final byte state)
215    {
216        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xB8);
217    }
218
219    /**
220     * Gets the next number that a different kind of 32-bit LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
221     * Does not allow state to be 0. If given all int values except 0 as arguments, will produce all ints except 0.
222     * Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you expect to call this again, such as
223     * with {@code (state = LFSR.determineInt(state))}, which will ensure the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up
224     * (such as having a period of ((2 to the 32) minus 1), or the guarantee that every number from 1 to ((2 to the 32)
225     * minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
226     * @param state any long other than 0
227     * @return the next int that a 32-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
228     */
229    public static int determineInt(final int state)
230    {
231        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xA3000000);
232    }
233
234    /**
235     * Gets the next positive long that a different kind of 63-bit LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
236     * Does not allow state to be 0 or negative. If given all positive long values (not including 0) as arguments, will
237     * produce all longs greater than 0. Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you
238     * expect to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determinePositiveLong(state))}, which will ensure
239     * the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 63) minus 1), or the guarantee
240     * that every number from 1 to ((2 to the 63) minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
241     * @param state any positive long, not including 0
242     * @return the next int that a 63-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
243     */
244    public static long determinePositiveLong(final long state)
245    {
246        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1L) & 0x6000000000000000L);
247    }
248
249    /**
250     * Gets the next positive int that a different kind of 31-bit LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
251     * Does not allow state to be 0 or negative. If given all positive int values (not including 0) as arguments, will
252     * produce all ints greater than 0. Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you
253     * expect to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determinePositiveInt(state))}, which will ensure the
254     * long-term properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 31) minus 1), or the guarantee
255     * that every number from 1 to ((2 to the 31) minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
256     * <br>
257     * A potential benefit of using this particular LFSR type is that the period is a prime number, 2147483647; this can
258     * sometimes be relevant if you simultaneously get pseudo-random numbers from sources of randomness with different
259     * periods that are "relatively co-prime" (that is, they share no common factors other than 1). This case lengthens
260     * the total period of the combined generators significantly, generally multiplying the periods together to get the
261     * combined period, as opposed to other cases that may simply add them together.
262     * @param state any positive int, not including 0
263     * @return the next int that a 31-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
264     */
265    public static int determinePositiveInt(final int state)
266    {
267        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0x48000000);
268    }
269
270    /**
271     * Gets the next int that a different kind of LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
272     * Does not allow state to be {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}, nor will this produce a result of {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}
273     * (as long as {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} was not the input). If given all int values except
274     * {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} as arguments, will produce all ints in the range {@code [-2147483647,2147483647]},
275     * including 0 but not -2147483648 (the minimum int). Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to
276     * state if you expect to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determineIntSymmetrical(state))}, which
277     * will ensure the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 32) minus 1), or
278     * the guarantee that every int except {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} will be generated once per period).
279     * <br>
280     * This is called Symmetrical because it produces the same amount of positive and negative numbers, instead of the
281     * normal generation of more negative ones (due to how ints are represented, the min value is always further from 0
282     * than the max value for any signed integer type).
283     * @param state any int other than -2147483648 (0x80000000), which is {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}; can produce 0
284     * @return the next int other than -2147483648 that an LFSR would produce with the given state
285     */
286    public static int determineIntSymmetrical(final int state)
287    {
288        return ((state ^ 0x80000000) >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xA3000000));
289    }
290
291    /**
292     * Gets the next number that an LFSR would produce using {@link #nextInt(int)} if its state was {@code state} and
293     * {@code bound} was passed to nextInt(). Does not allow state to be 0, but bound can be negative, which causes this
294     * not to produce positive numbers. This method is very predictable and its use is not encouraged; prefer using
295     * {@link #determineBounded(int, int)}.
296     * @param state any long other than 0
297     * @param bound the exclusive bound on the result as an int; does better if the bound is not too high (below 10000?)
298     * @return the next value that {@link LFSR#determine(long)} would produce with the given state, but limited to bound; can return 0
299     */
300    public static int determineBounded(final long state, int bound)
301    {
302        return (bound = (int)((bound * (state >>> 1 & 0xFFFFFFFFL)) >> 32)) + (bound >>> 31);
303    }
304    /**
305     * Gets an int using {@link #determineInt(int)} and bounds it to fit between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive).
306     * Does not allow state to be 0, but bound can be negative, which causes this not to produce positive numbers.
307     * @param state any int other than 0
308     * @param bound the exclusive bound on the result as an int; does better if the bound is not too high (below 10000?)
309     * @return the next int that {@link LFSR#determineInt(int)} would produce with the given state, but limited to bound; can return 0
310     */
311    public static int determineBounded(final int state, int bound)
312    {
313        return (bound = (int)((bound * ((state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xA3000000)) & 0xFFFFFFFFL)) >> 32)) + (bound >>> 31);
314    }
315}
